page.title: 04St.MICHAEL'S SHEBBEAR
page.content: The Parish Church of Shebbear goes back to 1150, as its Norman entrance testifies. It has two parallel aisles, the south aisle dating back to 1450 and built by Lady Prendergast whose effigy is set into the south wall. It has barrel shaped vaulting, the ceiling having been removed to allow air to circulate. A screen across the chancel was erected in 1933 by a previous vicar. The Jacobean pulpit is a fine feature. The Church seats 176 people, and has an average congregation of 25 to 30. Morning service is held every Sunday. The Churchyard is spacious and has 385 graves, dating as far back as 1760. There is a modern two manual pipe organ. Many of the hassocks have been attractively embroidered by ladies of the Congregation. The choir consists of older boys and girls.
